channel.title: The future of java?
channel.description:
So what thought's have you of Java's future, will be there new programming language which replace Java? Current direction what seems Java has the network(JSP, servlets ...) part also the JavaFX (is it failure or not). Popularity has gained also the Mobile devices new platforms Android.
So what you think of javaFX?? :D :confused: :|

item.title: The future of java?
item.dc:creator: @cows1471 cows1471
item.description:
@cows1471 wrote:

Its the next windows OS

Read full topic

item.title: The future of java?
item.dc:creator: @frank frank_
item.description:
@frank wrote:

[quote=“BAsh, post:31, topic:311554”]Do what windoze did (wow they did something right for once!):

  • Make a thin pseudo-vm. If you run on old API you get to stuck in the vm. Its just a compatibility layer so everything works and methods are just thin wrappers of their newer counterparts.
  • Everything else can run ‘natively’.
    That way everything can run, you can ‘break’ the API and there is no issue of backwards compatibility.[/quote]uhhhhhh what

that would solve forwards compatibility, but not backwards

Read full topic

item.title: The future of java?
item.dc:creator: @blah_bah7 blah bah7
item.description:
@blah_bah7 wrote:

Mopman:

are you 12 years old? cuz if so, well that probably still won’t happen

I’m 16, I have time.

Read full topic

item.title: The future of java?
item.dc:creator: @BAsh BAsh
item.description:
@BAsh wrote:

Do what windoze did (wow they did something right for once!):

  • Make a thin pseudo-vm. If you run on old API you get to stuck in the vm. Its just a compatibility layer so everything works and methods are just thin wrappers of their newer counterparts.
  • Everything else can run ‘natively’.
    That way everything can run, you can ‘break’ the API and there is no issue of backwards compatibility.

Read full topic

item.title: The future of java?
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

In Sun’s defence, their developers are well aware of the flaws in their API.

It would be great if they broke backwards compatibility. I have no doubts that, if such a thing occurred, the language would most likely become the best language ever.

Read full topic

item.title: The future of java?
item.dc:creator: @BAsh BAsh
item.description:
@BAsh wrote:

ollie123:

In my opinion, JavaFX will never top Adobe Flash. As for Java, i’d say that it has been built upon way to slowly. I am anticipating the release of JDK 7, however sometimes I think that java is a dead-end.

Long live browser video + javascript. The flash / silverlight killer.

Read full topic

item.title: The future of java?
item.dc:creator: @zstars zstars
item.description:
@zstars wrote:

Java will certainly evolve, but it’s been doing so way too slowly. Java 7 has been under development for years and yet it isn’t even going to add all these many features to the actual language. Improved GC, dynamic types handling, imp. anotations, and modularization basically. And only improved anotations (nonnull ones) will probably have a noticeable effect for the programmer.

Read full topic

item.title: The future of java?
item.dc:creator: @frank frank_
item.description:
@frank wrote:

needs more ignorance itt

Read full topic

item.title: The future of java?
item.dc:creator: @West7man West7man
item.description:
@West7man wrote:

Since there are a huge number of java mobile games I don’t think that java is going to be dead for mobile phones… Android is capable of supporting J2ME. I think that even for Android there will be a lot new Java mobile apps.
I like java because there is only one library on every platform that I need to use but in c++ for example, c++ has different libraries on linux and on windows… That means relearning a lot of commands/functions if you want to switch your OS.
About JavaFX? It’s like Vista - Just wait until a new big release of JavaFX comes out and hope it will be good… Just like windows 7 did after Vista.
Btw there are unlocked AT&T G1 Android phones sold on e-bay for around $120. They ship all around the world. The G1 is a prototype but it’s still pretty good and cool.

Read full topic

item.title: The future of java?
item.dc:creator: @javedman0208 javedman0208
item.description:
@javedman0208 wrote:

For me is the JavaFX total failure, I dont like the new syntax. But the Android will be more popular and popular also I hope the devices will be cheaper.

What I am waiting from Sun is the develop desktop API Swing or any newer. They only wasted their money in this project and they haven’t done any big updates. Java’s GUI sections is pretty dead, QT has canceled the develop (http://www.qtsoftware.com…t-jambi-release-available). I hoped more of Swing

Read full topic

item.title: The future of java?
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

I knew someone would take my ‘uphill’ comment and turn it around on me.

Jerk…

Seriously though, I’ve been programming in java since 1.3 or so, and it has made huge strides in the short time since then, it used to be far worse than it is now. Trust me.

item.title: The future of java?
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

I think java’s future is strong. It has been growing better and stronger since it first came out, and with the move to an officially open-source Java 7 it can only be uphill from here.
